revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Dichotomous Key/Spheniscidae]]

==Somatosensory Perception of Whiskers== === Introduction === {{multiple image | image1 = Overview of Whisker System.png | width1 = {{#expr: (250 * 388/520) round 0}} | caption1 = Figure 1A. Overview of the whisker system in rats | image2 = Ascending pathways from whisker to barrel cortex.png | width2 = {{#expr: (250 * 624/1286) round 0}} | caption2 = Figure 1B. System level description of the ascending pathways from whiskers to barrel cortex. }} The barrel Cortex is a specialized region in somatosensory cortex responsible for processing the tactile information from whiskers. As every other cortical region, the barrel cortex also preserves the columnar organization which plays a crucial role in information processing. Information from each whisker is represented in separate, discrete columns analogous to “barrels”, hence the name barrel cortex. Rodents use whiskers constantly to acquire sensory information from the environment. Given their nocturnal nature, tactile information carried by whisker forms the primary sensory signals to build a perceptual map of the environment. The whiskers on the snouts of mice and rats serve as arrays of highly sensitive detectors for acquiring tactile information as shown in Figure 1 A and B. By using their whiskers, rodents can build spatial representations of their environment, locate objects, and perform fine-grain texture discrimination. Somatosensory whisker-related processing is highly organized into stereotypical maps, which occupy a large portion of the rodent brain. During exploration and palpation of objects, the whiskers are under motor control, often executing rapid large-amplitude rhythmic sweeping movements, and this sensory system is therefore an attractive model for investigating active sensory processing and sensory-motor integration. In these animals, a large part of the neocortex is dedicated to the processing of information from the whiskers. Since rodents are nocturnal, visual information is relatively poor and they rely heavily on the tactile information from whiskers. Perhaps the most remarkable specialization of this sensory system is the primary somatosensory ‘‘barrel’’ cortex, where each whisker is represented by a discrete and well-defined structure in layer 4. These layer 4 barrels are somatotopically arranged in an almost identical fashion to the layout of the whiskers on the snout i.e. bordering whiskers are represented in adjacent cortical areas [1]. Sensorimotor integration of whisker related activity leads to pattern discrimination and enables rodents to have a reliable map of the environment. This is an interesting model to study because rodents use whisker to “see” and this cross modality sensory information processing could help us to improve the life of humans, who are deprived of one sensory modality. Specifically, blind people can be trained to use somatosensory information to build a spatial map of the environment [2]. === Pathways carrying whisker information to Barrel Cortex === {| class="wikitable" width=100%; |- | {{hide |Pathways carrying whisker information to Barrel Cortex | [[File:Ascending pathway of rodent whisker-related sensorimotor system.png|thumb|Figure 2. Schematic demonstrating the ascending pathway of rodent whisker-related sensorimotor system.]] The tactile information from the whiskers on the snouts is carried through the trigeminal nerves, which terminate at the trigeminal nucleus as shown in Figure 2. The ascending pathway starts with the primary afferents in the trigeminal ganglion (TG) transducing whisker vibrations into neuronal signals, and projecting to the trigeminal brainstem complex (TN). The TN consists of the principal nucleus (PrV), and the spinal sub-nuclei (interpolarisSpVi; caudalisSpVc; the detailed connectivity of the oralis sub-nucleus is unknown and is omitted in the figure). The SpVi falls into a caudal and rostral part (SpVic and SpVir). The classical mono-whisker lemniscal pathway (lemniscal 1) originates in PrV barrelettes, and projects via VPM barreloid cores to primary somatosensory cortex (S1) barrel columns. A second lemniscal pathway originating from PrV has been recently discovered which carries multi-whisker signals via barreloid heads to septa (and dysgranular zone) of S1. The extra-lemniscal pathway originates in SPVic and carries multi-whisker signals via barreloid tails in VPM to the secondary somatosensory area. Finally, the parelemniscal pathway originates in SpVir and carries multi-whisker signals via POm to S1, S2, and primary motor area (M1). The different colours of connections indicate three principal pathways through which associative coupling between the sensorimotor cortical areas may be realized. Black indicates direct cortico-cotical connections. Blue shows cortico-thalamic cascades. Brown represents cortico-sub-cortical loops. Projections of S1 and S2 may open or close the lemniscal gate (i.e. gate signal flow through PrV) by modulating intrinsic TN circuitry. [[File:Processing of whisker-related sensory information in barrel cortex.png|thumb|Figure 3.Processing of whisker-related sensory information in barrel cortex. System level description of the pathways involved in the propagation of information from whiskers to cortex & columnar organization of the barrel cortex which receives information from single whisker. ]] The sensory neurons make excitatory glutamatergic synapses in the trigeminal nuclei of the brain stem. Trigemino-thalamic neurons in the principal trigeminal nucleus are organized into somatotopically arranged ‘‘barrelettes,’’ each receiving strong input from a single whisker as shown in (Figure 3). The principal trigeminal neurons project to the ventral posterior medial (VPM) nucleus of the thalamus, which is also somatotopically laid out into anatomical units termed ‘‘barreloids’’ VPM neurons respond rapidly and precisely to whisker deflection, with one ‘‘principal’’ whisker evoking stronger responses than all others. The axons of VPM neurons within individual barreloids project to the primary somatosensory neocortex forming discrete clusters in layer 4, which form the basis of the ‘‘barrel’’ map as shown in Figure 3. }} |} === Whisker information processing in Barrel Cortex with specialized local microcircuit === The deflection of a whisker is thought to open mechano-gated ion channels in nerve endings of sensory neurons innervating the hair follicle (although the molecular signalling machinery remains to be identified). The resulting depolarization evokes action potential firing in the sensory neurons of the infraorbital branch of the trigeminal nerve. The transduction through mechanical deformation is similar to the hair cells in the inner ear; in this case the contact of whiskers with the objects causes the mechano-gated ion channels to open. Cation-permeable ion channels let positively charged ions into the cells and causes depolarization, eventually leading to generation of action potentials. A single sensory neuron only fires action potentials to deflection of one specific whisker. The innervation of the hair follicle shows a diversity of nerve endings, which may be specialized for detecting different types of sensory input [3]. The layer 4 barrel map is arranged almost identically to the layout of the whiskers on the snout of the rodent. There are several recurrent connections in layer 4 and it sends axons to layer 2/3 neurons, which integrates information from other cortical regions like primary motor cortex. These intra-cortical and inter-cortical connections enable the rodents to achieve stimulus discrimination capabilities and to extract optimal information from the incoming tactile stimulus. Also, these projections play a crucial role in integrating somatosensory information with motor output. Information from whiskers is processed in the barrel cortex with specialized local microcircuits formed to extract optimal information about the environment. These cortical microcircuits are composed of excitatory and inhibitory neurons as shown in Figure 4. [[File:Local Microcircuit in Barrel cortex.png|thumb|Figure 4.Local Microcircuit in Barrel cortex. Left: schematic representation of the cortical layers (barrels within L4 in cyan ) with examples of typical dendritic morphologies of excitatory cortical neurons (in red , an L2 neuron; in violet , a spiny stellate L4 cell; in green , an L5B pyramidal neuron). Right: schematic representation of the main excitatory connections between cortical layers within a barrel column (black).]] === Learning whisker based object discrimination & texture differentiation === Rodents move their sensors to collect information, and these movements are guided by sensory input. When action sequences are required to achieve success in novel tasks, interactions between movement and sensation underlie motor control [4] and complex learned behaviours [5]. The motor cortex has important roles in learning motor skills [6-9], but its function in learning sensorimotor associations is unknown. The neural circuits underlying sensorimotor integration are beginning to be mapped. Different motor cortex layers harbour excitatory neurons with distinct inputs and projections [10-12]. Outputs to motor centres in the brain stem and spinal cord arise from pyramidal tract-type neurons in layer 5B (L5B). Within motor cortex, excitation descends from L2/3 to L5 [13, 14]. Input from somatosensory cortex impinges preferentially onto L2/3 neurons. L2/3 neurons [10] therefore directly link somatosensation and control of movements. In one of the recent studies [15], mice were trained head fixed in a vibrissa-based object-detection task while imaging populations of neurons [16]. Following a sound, a pole was moved to one of several target positions within reach of the whiskers (the ‘go’ stimulus) or to an out-of-reach position (the ‘no-go’ stimulus). Target and out-of-reach locations were arranged along the anterior–posterior axis; the out-of reach position was most anterior. Mice searched for the pole with one whisker row, the C row, and reported the pole as ‘present’ by licking, or ‘not present’ by withholding licking. Licking on go trials (hit) was rewarded with water, whereas licking on no-go trials (false alarm) was punished with a time-out during which the trial was stopped for 2 seconds. Trials without licking (no-go, correct rejection, go, and miss) were not rewarded or punished. All mice showed learning within the first two or three sessions. Performance reached expert levels after three to six training sessions. Learning the behavioural task was directly dependent on the motor related behaviour. Naive mice whisked occasionally in a manner unrelated to trail structure. Thus, object detection relies on a sequence of actions, linked by sensory cues. An auditory cue triggers whisking during the sampling period. Contact between whisker and object causes licking for a water reward during a response period. Silencing vM1 indicates that this task requires the motor cortex; with vM1 silenced, task-dependent whisking persisted, but was reduced in amplitude and repeatability, and task performance dropped. === Neural Correlates of Sensorimotor learning mechanism === Coding of touch in the motor cortex is consistent with direct input from vS1 to the imaged neurons. A model based on population coding of individual behavioural features also predicted motor behaviours. Accurate decoding of whisking amplitude, whisking set-point and lick rate suggests that vM1 controls these slowly varying motor parameters, as expected from previous motor cortex and neurophysiological experiments. === References === 1 Feldmeyer D, Brecht M, Helmchen F, Petersen CCH, Poulet JFA, Staiger JF, Luhmann HJ, Schwarz C."Barrel cortex function" Progress in Neurobiology 2013, 103 : 3-27. 2 Lahav O, Mioduser D. "Multisensory virtual environment for supporting blind persons' acquisition of spatial cognitive mapping, orientation, and mobility skills." Academia.edu 2002. 3 Alloway KD. "Information processing streams in rodent barrel cortex: The differential functions of barrel and septal circuits." Cereb Cortex 2008, 18(5):979-989. 4 Scott SH. "Inconvenient truths about neural processing in primary motor cortex." The Journal of physiology 2008, 586(5):1217-1224. 5 Wolpert DM, Diedrichsen J, Flanagan JR. "Principles of sensorimotor learning." Nature reviews Neuroscience 2011, 12(12):739-751. 6 Wise SP, Moody SL, Blomstrom KJ, Mitz AR. "Changes in motor cortical activity during visuomotor adaptation." Experimental brain research Experimentelle Hirnforschung Experimentation cerebrale 1998, 121(3):285-299. 7 Rokni U, Richardson AG, Bizzi E, Seung HS. "Motor learning with unstable neural representations." Neuron 2007, 54(4):653-666. 8 Komiyama T, Sato TR, O'Connor DH, Zhang YX, Huber D, Hooks BM, Gabitto M, Svoboda K. "Learning-related fine-scale specificity imaged in motor cortex circuits of behaving mice." Nature 2010, 464(7292):1182-1186. 9 Hosp JA, Pekanovic A, Rioult-Pedotti MS, Luft AR. "Dopaminergic projections from midbrain to primary motor cortex mediate motor skill learning." The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience 2011, 31(7):2481-2487. 10 Keller A. "Intrinsic synaptic organization of the motor cortex." Cereb Cortex 1993, 3(5):430-441. 11 Mao T, Kusefoglu D, Hooks BM, Huber D, Petreanu L, Svoboda K. "Long-range neuronal circuits underlying the interaction between sensory and motor cortex." Neuron 2011, 72(1):111-123. 12 Hooks BM, Hires SA, Zhang YX, Huber D, Petreanu L, Svoboda K, Shepherd GM. "Laminar analysis of excitatory local circuits in vibrissal motor and sensory cortical areas." PLoS biology 2011, 9(1):e1000572. 13 Anderson CT, Sheets PL, Kiritani T, Shepherd GM. "Sublayer-specific microcircuits of corticospinal and corticostriatal neurons in motor cortex." Nature neuroscience 2010, 13(6):739-744. 14 Kaneko T, Cho R, Li Y, Nomura S, Mizuno N. "Predominant information transfer from layer III pyramidal neurons to corticospinal neurons." The Journal of comparative neurology 2000, 423(1):52-65. 15 O'Connor DH, Clack NG, Huber D, Komiyama T, Myers EW, Svoboda K. "Vibrissa-based object localization in head-fixed mice." The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience 2010, 30(5):1947-1967. 16 O'Connor DH, Peron SP, Huber D, Svoboda K. "Neural activity in barrel cortex underlying vibrissa-based object localization in mice." Neuron 2010, 67(6):1048-1061. 17 Shaner NC, Campbell RE, Steinbach PA, Giepmans BN, Palmer AE, Tsien RY. "Improved monomeric red, orange and yellow fluorescent proteins derived from Discosoma sp. red fluorescent protein." Nature biotechnology 2004, 22(12):1567-1572. 18 Tian L, Hires SA, Mao T, Huber D, Chiappe ME, Chalasani SH, Petreanu L, Akerboom J, McKinney SA, Schreiter ER. "Imaging neural activity in worms, flies and mice with improved GCaMP calcium indicators." Nature methods 2009, 6(12):875-881.

page.title: Biological Physics/How work, pressure, and volume are related

revision.text:
== The Ideal Gas Law ==
The first concept we will derive and study is the Ideal Gas Law. You may be familiar with the Ideal Gas Law in the form <math>{\it PV}={\it nRT}</math> from a general chemistry course, where ''P'' is the pressure, ''V'' is the volume, ''n'' is the number of moles of particles, ''R'' is the Ideal Gas Constant, and ''T'' is temperature. This equation can be used to describe a closed system filled with ideal (non-interacting, randomly moving) gas particles.
=== Derivation === Understanding and deriving this law from first principles is our first step to obtaining a grasp of thermal biophysics. Let's first write the Ideal Gas Law in a new manner. This is considered the more "physics-y" formulation of the Ideal Gas Law, and it is easier to derive. This new formulation is <math>{\it PV}={\it Nk}_{{B}}T</math>. The only difference between the two is that the latter contains an ''N'' that represents the number of particles in a system rather than the number of moles of particles. Also, the constant is no longer the Ideal Gas Constant ''R'' but Boltzmann's constant ''k<sub>B</sub>''. Boltzmann's constant relates energy with temperature at the level of each individual particle.
Consider a closed system of a cylinder and piston. The distance from the piston to the other side is ''x'', and the area of the piston (and the other side of the cylinder) is ''A''. The cylinder is filled with monatomic ideal gas particles that are moving ballistically and randomly around inside.
The cylinder in its current state is 3 dimensional. The particles are allowed to move up and down, left and right, and forward and backwards. However, imagine that we squeeze the cylinder down to an infinitely small tube such that the particles only have the ability to move only left and right. This greatly decreases the complexity of the proof as we only have to worry about one dimension rather than three.
[[File:Pistons.jpg|thumb|Piston and 1 dimensional piston to test the Ideal Gas Law]]
It is at this point that we should state a few assumptions of the proof thus far. Assumptions are important to understand as they give us guidance to the validity, applicability, and general understanding of the proof and consequent concepts that are drawn from it. First, we assume that all particles are moving at the same speed. At first glance, this assumption seems preposterous. However, when taken as a whole, a large number of particles (think ''1 x 10<sup>23</sup>'') do behave with an aggregate average speed. This idea of "average" is a concept that will reappear many times throughout statistical mechanics. This idea is only valid with large systems, but since that is what we are usually concerned with in thermal physics, then this assumption will hold.
The second assumption is that collisions are elastic and momentum is conserved. This means that when a particle with mass ''m'' and with velocity ''v'' collide with one of the ends of the container, then <math>p_{{i}}={\it mv}</math> and <math>p_{{f}}=-{\it mv}</math> where ''p<sub>i</sub>'' is the momentum of the particle before collision and ''p<sub>f</sub>'' is the momentum after collision.
You may recall that <math>F={\frac {{\it dp}}{{\it dt}}}</math>. So
:<math>\left| F \right| ={\frac { \left| \Delta p \right| }{\Delta t}}</math>
:<math>\left| F \right| ={\frac { \left| p_{{f}}-p_{{i}} \right| }{\Delta t}} </math>
:<math>\left| F \right| ={\frac { \left| {\it -mv}-mv \right| }{\Delta t}}</math>
:<math>\left| F \right| =2\,{\frac {{\it mv}}{\Delta t}}</math>
You may be wondering what value we chose for ''Δt''. We will let ''Δt'' be the time it takes for a particle to move from one end of the tube to the opposite end of the tube and collide. This restriction ensures that each and every particle collides exactly once with one side of the tube during time ''Δt''. Here, we make our third assumption that half of the particles will collide with the left end and the other half will collide with the right end. The sum of the force imparted by each individual particle that collides with the right end would give the total force felt on the right end from the particles. Or, more succinctly <math>F_{{{\it right}}}=\Sigma\,\,{\frac {2m_{{i}}v_{{i}}}{\Delta t}}</math> where ''i'' goes from 0 to only ''N/2'' since only half of the particles collide on the right side in the allotted time. Also, it should be noted that <math>F_{{{\it right}}}=-F_{{{\it left}}}</math> since the same number of particles collide on the left, but in opposite direction. This equation greatly simplifies down to :<math>F_{{{\it right}}}={\frac {N}{2}}{\frac {{\it 2mv}}{\Delta t}}</math> :<math>F_{{{\it right}}}={\frac {{\it Nmv}}{\Delta t}}</math>
Recall that pressure on one end of the tube ''P'' is the total force felt at that end divided by the area of the end <math>P_{{{\it right}}}={\frac {F_{{{\it right}}}}{A}}</math>.
By substitution, <math>P_{{{\it right}}}={\frac {{\it Nmv}}{A\Delta t}}</math>. Since <math>V={\it Ax}</math>, then after solving for ''A'', <math>P={\frac {{\it Nmvx}}{V\Delta t}}</math> by substitution. Remember what ''x'' represents: the total length of one end to the other of the tube. Since ''Δt'' was the time it took for a particle to move from one end of the tube to the other, then it follows that <math>v={\frac {x}{\Delta t}}</math>. By substitution, <math>P={\frac {{{\it Nmv}}^{2}}{V}}</math>, or :<math>{\it PV}={{\it Nmv}}^{2}</math>
Now, we will invoke a principle that you may not have heard of before. According to the '''Equipartition Theorem''', any quadratic degree of freedom may store an average of <math>1/2\,k_{{B}}T</math> of energy. Since the velocity term is quadratic, then it follows the Equipartition Theorem. The Equipartition Theorem is not a theorem that is proven here; it will simply be assumed true. There are many degrees of freedom that need to be considered for these particles: translational, rotational, and vibrational motion. Since we have restricted ourselves to a one-dimensional system, then there is only one translational degree of freedom. There are in fact no degrees of rotational freedom. This may seem strange, but it is a phenomenon that arises from Quantum Mechanics. Since the particles are monatomic and spherical, it is impossible to distinguish one rotational configuration from another. This means that these rotational states admit no extra degree of freedom. There is no degree of freedom that arises from vibrational motion since the particles are monatomic. Therefore, the kinetic energy ''KE'' of the particle contains only 1 term <math>{\it KE}=1/2\,{{\it mv}}^{2}</math>. Since the kinetic energy is quadratic, then by the Equipartition Theorem <math>1/2\,{{\it mv}}^{2}=1/2\,k_{{B}}T</math>, or with a little simplification <math>{{\it mv}}^{2}=k_{{B}}T</math>. By substitution back into the pressure equation above, <math>{\it PV}={\it Nk}_{{B}}T</math>.
=== The Difference between ''n'' and ''N'' ===
Be sure that you do not get confused with the difference between ''n'' and ''N''. The number of moles in the ideal gas is denoted by ''n'' while the number of ''particles'' is denoted by ''N''. To a physicist, it is usually more helpful to think in terms of the particles rather than the number of moles. This will become exceptionally clear when we begin to study the amount of disorder in a system.
== Work ==
Now imagine an outside force is exerted on the piston. When a force is applied onto the system, the piston compresses by a certain distance ''Δx''. You may remember from an earlier physics class that ''Work'' can be calculated as <math>W=F \Delta x</math>. Since <math>F = PA</math>, then by substitution <math>W={PA} \Delta x</math>. Since ''AΔx'' is just the change in volume ''ΔV'', then <math>W={P} \Delta V</math>. Essentially, work shows the amount of energy that enters or leaves the system whenever the piston moves in or out. The primary focus in Thermal Physics is to keep track of the total energy in a system. It seems that one exchange of energy between systems is through the work that is either done on or being done by the system. Another type of energy that needs to be monitored is the amount of ''heat'' that enters or leaves the system. Ultimately, work and heat energy are the only two quantities to keep track of to determine the total change in energy. This gets us to the ''First Law of Thermodynamics'' :<math>U(total energy)=Q(heat)+W(work)</math>
More often than not, it may be more prevalent to measure a change in the energy of the system :<math> \Delta U = Q + W </math>, where the deltas (''Δ'') have been left off of the right side because heat and work are not necessarily conserved quantities.
=== Isothermal Processes ===
An isothermal process is a process that occurs while temperature remains constant. First, recall the state equation of an ideal gas <math>{\it PV}={\it Nk}_{{B}}T</math> or <math>P={\frac {{\it Nk}_{{B}}T}{V}}</math>. Also, recall that work in a system for constant temperature is <math>W=P \Delta V</math>. Since it is possible for both volume and pressure to change, and pressure can be written as a function of volume, then work can be written as a function dependent on volume <math>W={\frac {{\it Nk}_{{B}}T\Delta V}{V}}</math>. Now, if you take small increments of <math>\Delta V</math> or <math>dV</math> and then added them all up to obtain the total change in volume, then work could be calculated as<math>\int_{Vi}^{Vf} {\frac{Nk_{B}T}{V}}\,dV</math>. Since an isothermal process is being considered, then <math>Nk_{B}T</math> is constant and can be pulled out of the integral. After integrating, <math>W={\it Nk}_{{B}}T \left( \ln \left( V_{{f}} \right) -\ln \left( V_{{i}} \right) \right) </math>. By rules logarithms, <math>W={\it Nk}_{{B}}T\ln \left( {\frac {V_{{f}}}{V_{{i}}}} \right)</math>. For such an isothermal process (where the temperature remains constant), all of the energy that enters or leaves a system can be found with this work equation.
=== All about Perspective===
When the piston is compressed, we perform work on the system and the volume decreases. As can be seen from the above equation, a final volume that is smaller than the initial volume will give a negative value. This means that if we want to determine whether energy is entering (positive work) or leaving (negative work) a system, then the work equation needs to have a sign flipped <math>W=-{\it Nk}_{{B}}T\ln \left( {\frac {V_{{f}}}{V_{{i}}}} \right)</math>. Or once again from the rules of logarithms, <math>W={\it Nk}_{{B}}T\ln \left( {\frac {V_{{i}}}{V_{{f}}}} \right)</math>. This illustrates an important concern in thermal physics. It is imperative that the energy being discussed is qualified in terms of the ‘’system’’ or its ‘’surroundings’’. In most cases, a negative value stands for energy leaving the system and a positive value indicates energy entering the system. This being the case, our equation for work must be written as <math>W = -P \Delta V</math> to ensure that compression (decrease in volume) leads to positive work on the system.
== The First Law in Biology and Chemistry == {{BookCat}}
{{auto navigation|Boyles Law|The Zeroth & First Laws}}

bye Source:[[Wikibooks]]

== Key Terms == ;Application software :Application software is all of the programs on a computer that to e specific task. i.e. playing video games, or typing a paper.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Application_software]]</ref>
;Boot :Booting up a computer is the process where you first turn it on after a time where the computer is off. The computer does a system check to ensure everything is operational between the OS, Bios, and hardware.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Boot_up]]</ref>
;Computer :A computer is any electronic device that is programmable, accepts input, processes that data, and produces an output.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Computer]]</ref>
;Domain name :A domain name is a text based name that is unique to each computer on the internet.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Domain_name]]</ref>
;Email :Email or electronic mail is a digital message sent from one user to another through a network or the internet.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Electronic_mail]]</ref>
;Embedded computer :An embedded computer is a small computing device that does a specific function for that device.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Embedded_system]]</ref>
;Hardware :Hardware is the physical, tangible parts of a computer.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Computer_hardware]]</ref>
;Input :Input is where you would enter data to the computer, usually be means of peripherals. Such as keyboard and mouse.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Input_device]]</ref>
;Internet :Simply put the internet is a network of networks, connecting millions of computers together.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Internet]]</ref>
;Internet service provider :The internet being a network of networks, you must be able to connect to said network and the only way is through an internet service provider(ISP). Generally the ISP is a large company that you would pay monthly for this service.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Internet_service_provider]]</ref>
;Operating system :An operating system (OS) is the major system software that controls all other system applications, and manages the computer hardware. All PC's need an OS.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Operating_system]]</ref>
;Output :Output occurs after the computer processes the data you inputted and displays said data.<ref>[[Wikipedia: Input/output]]</ref>
== Review Questions== 1. Keyboards and mice are two forms of _______ devices?
2. Microsoft word and windows media player are examples of ________
3. Comcast and AT&T are _________
4. The initial start up for a computer is the ____ sequence.
5. Before it is information it is ____.
6. The ___ helps to identify websites by a specific name.
7. The chip inside the computer which is essentially the "brain" of the whole system is called the ______
8. The physical parts of a computer are _______
9. A network of networks is called the ______
10. When sending a digital message from one computer to another you are using your _______
==References== {{reflist}}
==Answers== 1. Input devices
2. Application software
3. ISP(Internet service providers
4. Boot
5. Data
6. Web address or domain name
7. CPU
8. Hardware
9. Internet
10. E-mail

'''How to read txt file into R with fixed width and column?'''
1. Ignore the ordinal numbers from 1 to 11 2. Read data point from 6 to 19 3. Name each column with item 1 to item 14 4 Compare the value from column 6 to 19 with key file, which is dichotomous values.
The final dataset would i
Original 1 24231143143524 2 24332341321313 3 14221244121231 4 34121132325352 5 34332141121311 6 34123241321111 7 34241241121212 8 24131232144423 9 34142232341121 10 34141345124232 11 44242441141411
Processed Item 1 Item 2 Item 3 . . . Item 14 0 1 0 . . . 1

A bidding system is a collection of conventional agreements to be used. A system should cover all frequent bidding sequences, including all [[Bridge/Glossary#Opening bids|opening bids]], responses to opening bids and all [[Bridge/Glossary#Overcall|overcalls]].
== Classification == * A natural is [[#Green Systems|green]] * A system using 1♣ or 1♦ as artificial strong opening (usually showing 15/16/17 or more [[Bridge/Glossary#HCP|HCP]]) is [[#Blue Systems|blue]] * A system that contains a convention that falls into the [[Bridge/Bidding Conventions#Highly Unusual Methods|highly unusual method]] category is [[#Yellow Systems|yellow(HUM)]] * A system that does not fall into the above 3 categories is [[#Red Systems|red]]
== Green Systems ==
== Blue Systems ==
== Red Systems ==
== Yellow Systems == {{BookCat}}

= Goals =
Welcome to the first unit of the Elementary Spanish guide!
In this lesson you will learn how to talk about your family. Most of the material will be in the present tense so it will focus on talking about your family today. Future lessons will cover talking about your family growing up or planning future activity with your family. For this lesson just focus on the present.
By the end you will be able to count to 10, know a dozen words for various family members, and be able to ask and answer some basic questions about your family in conversation with other parents.
= Lessons =
All of these lessons focus on the same topic, talking about family, but each one is focused on the material you need to talk with different groups of people: your fellow parents following this guide, your children, and personal acquaintances who already know Spanish.
You should start with the first lessons, "[[/Beginner/|1. Talking with each other]]", and then proceed to the rest as you have time. The language exchange events will only focus on these "Talking with each other" lessons so no need to worry if you do not have time for the other ones before the next meeting. Each unit will follow this pattern.
* '''[[/Beginner/|1. Talking with each other]]''' * '''[[/Intermediate/|2. Talking with your children]]''' * '''[[/Advanced/|3. Talking with acquaintances]]'''
= Resources =
These are some handy phrases for language students, especially if you begin practicing with acquaintances and native speakers in the community. If you ever get stuck in conversation, these phrases can help smooth everything out and get you back on your conversational feet.
== Helper phrases == {| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>I am learning Spanish.</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Estoy aprendiendo español.</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Can I practice my Spanish with you?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Puedo practicar mi español con tigo?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Can you repeat that?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Puede repetir eso?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Can you say that slower?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Lo puede decir mas despacio?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Thank you for your help.</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Gracias por su ayuda.</center>
|}

== Goals == By the end of this lesson, you should be able to ask and answer basic questions about your family, or any other family.
== Vocabulary ==
[http://wikiotics.org/es/Family1 Word match activity]
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>First</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Primer</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Second</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Segundo</center>

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>His</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>De el … de+el= del</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Her</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>De ella </center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Wife/husband</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>esposa/esposo</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mom</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mama…mami…madre</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Dad</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Papa…papi…padre</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Son</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Hijo</center>

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Brother</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Hermano</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Sister</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Hermana</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Family</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Familia</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>One</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Uno</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Two</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Dos</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Three</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Tres</center>

|}
== Possible questions in an exchange == {| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>How many are in your family?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuántos hay en tu familia?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Which one is yours?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuál es tuya? ¿Cuál es tuyo?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>My child is ________.</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mi hijo/hija es _______.</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>How old is she/he?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuántos años tiene?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>What is your name?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cómo te llamas?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>What is his/her name?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cómo se llama él/ella?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>What grade is she/he in?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿En qué grado está él/ella?</center>
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part1 Question practice activity]
''Please keep in mind that in these basic lessons, we are not including the formal form of address "USTED". This is the form of address you would use when speaking to someone in a superior social position. This form is much less commonly used by adults in a community of equals, like our community, so we will not be covering it in the introductory lessons. For now it is enough to know that you are learning the informal, every day, Spanish and that there is a more formal variety you could use.''
== Example dialogues == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Family_Beginner_2?oldid=3319 Dialogue 1 audio activity]
=== Dialogue 1 ===
In the following dialogue, Michelle and Daniel are meeting for the first time. Michelle has two children and Daniel has one. They are exchanging details about their kids.
Michelle: Hola. Me llamo Michelle. ¿Cómo te llamas?
Daniel: Hola Michelle. Yo me llamo Daniel.
Michelle: Mucho gusto. ¿Cuál es tu hijo o hija?
Daniel: Mi hija es María. Ella tiene seis años. Está en el primer grado.
Michelle: O. Que bien. Yo tengo dos hijos. Se llaman Jaime y Jazmín.
Daniel: Que bonitos nombres. ¿Cuántos años tienen?
Michelle: Jaime tiene cuatro años y Jazmín tiene ocho años.
Notice how “tiene” was used for singular and “tienen” was used for plural.
=== Dialogue 2 === [http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Family_Beginner_1 Dialogue 2 audio activity]
In the following dialogue, Matthew and Eliza catch up. They haven’t seen each other in a while and inquire about each others’ families.
Matthew: ¡Hola Eliza!
Eliza: ¡Hola Matthew! Mucho tiempo sin verte. ¿Cómo está tu familia?
Matthew: Mi papá está muy bien. Va a la escuela para aprender inglés. Mi mamá también está bien. Ella está trabajando mucho. Mi esposa está visitando a su familia en Tejas. Se llevó a los niños.
Eliza: Entonces, ¿te quedaste solito?
Matthew: Solito con las plantas. ¿Como está tu familia?
Eliza: Mi familia esta creciendo. Voy a tener otro bebé.
Matthew: ¡Felicidades!
Eliza: Si. Éramos cinco y ahora somos seis. Me encanta el numero seis.
== Links and Extra Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Family1 Word match activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part1 Question practice activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Family_Beginner_2?oldid=3319 Dialogue 1 audio activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Family_Beginner_1 Dialogue 2 audio activity]

== Goals == By the end of this lesson, you should be able to ask and answer questions about family member's birthdays and phone numbers.
== Vocabulary == === People descriptions === {| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Older</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mayor</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Younger</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Menor</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Bigger</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Más grande</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Smaller</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Más pequeño(a) /chiquito(a)</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Phone</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Teléfono</center>

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Day</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Día</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Month</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mes</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Year</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Año</center>
|}
=== Months of the year === {| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>January</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>enero</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>February</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>febrero</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>March</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>marzo</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>April</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>abril</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>May</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>mayo</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>June</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>junio</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>July</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>julio</center>

|}
===Possible questions to ask your child===
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>What is your older/younger sister’s/brother’s name?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cómo se llama tu hermano/hermana mayor/menor?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>When is your birthday?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuándo es tu cumpleaños?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>When is your sister’s/brother’s birthday?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuándo es el cumpleaños de tu hermana/hermano?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>What is your phone number?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Cuál es tu número de teléfono?</center>
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part2 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == ''In the following dialogue, a father has a conversation with his daughter. He is practicing asking questions in Spanish, while his daughter is practicing answering questions in complete sentences. Notice how she turns the questions into complete sentences.''
Father: Hola hija.
Daughter: Hola papá. ¿Dónde está mami?
Father: Mami está en la tienda. ¿Cómo se llama tu mamá?
Daughter: Mi mamá se llama Lupe.
Father: ¿Cómo se llama tu hermano mayor?
Daughter: Mi hermano mayor se llama Julián.
Father: ¿Cuántos años tiene Julián?
Daughter: Julián tiene cuatro años.
Father: ¿Cuándo es el cumpleaños de Julián?
Daughter: El cumpleaños de Julián es el cinco de agosto.
Father: ¿Qué año?
Daughter: El dos mil once.
Father: ¿Qué es nuestro número de teléfono?
Daughter: Nuestro número de teléfono es cinco cinco cinco dos tres uno cuatro.
Father: ¡Que bien hablas español!
[http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Familiy_Intermediate Podcast activity]
== Links and Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Present_Familiy_Intermediate Podcast activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Family_2 Word Match Activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part2 Question practice activity]

== Goals == By the end of this lesson, you should be able to ask a strangers about their families and know the names of different sporting activities in Spanish.
==Vocabulary== {| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Goes to</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Va ha</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Sports</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Deportes</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Soccer</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Futbol</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Baseball</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Béisbol</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Basketball</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Basquetbol</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Track/running</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Correr</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Volleyball</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Voleibol</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Married</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Casado/casada</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Siblings</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Hermanos/hermanas</center>
|}
==Possible questions to ask==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Do you have any kids?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Tiene hijos?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>My kids go to_____</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Mis hijos/hijas van a _____.</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Where do your kids go?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Dónde van tus hijos?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Do they play any sports?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Juegan deportes tus hijos/hijas?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Are you married?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Estás casado/casada?</center>
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>Do you have any siblings?</center> | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| <center>¿Tienes hermanos/hermanas?</center>
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part3 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == ''In the following dialogue, two strangers meet on the train. Alejandro is learning Spanish and asks Francisco if he could practice his Spanish with him. They converse about their families.''
Alejandro: Hola. Mi nombre es Alejandro. Estoy aprendiendo español. ¿Puedo practicar contigo?
Francisco: Mucho gusto Alejandro. Me llamo Francisco. Sí, puedes practicar conmigo.
Alejandro: Mi familia es de Wisconsin. ¿De donde es tu familia?
Francisco: Mi familia es del D.F. en Mejico.
Alejandro: Me encanta la comida Mejicana.
Francisco: Es muy rica.
Alejandro: ¿Estás casado?
Francisco: Sí. Estoy casado.
Alejandro: Yo también estoy casado. ¿Tienes hijos?
Francisco: Sí tengo, dos hijos.
Alejandro: Mi esposa es maestra. ¿Cual escuela van tus hijos?
Francisco: Mis hijos van a P.S. 1002.
Alejandro: ¡Mi esposa enseña ahí! También es entrenadora de beisbol. ¿Juegan deportes tus hijos?
Francisco: ¡Qué mundo tan pequeño! Sí juegan deportes pero no juegan béisbol. Ellos juegan basquetbol. ¿Tienes hijos?
Alejandro: No tenemos hijos.
Francisco: ¿Tienes hermanos?
Alejandro: Sí. Tengo dos hermanas. Ellas viven es Wisconsin.
Francisco: Bueno, este es mi parada. Hablas español muy bien.
Alejandro: Gracias por practicar conmigo.
== Links and Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Family3 Picture match activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family1-Part3 Question practice activity]

revision.comment: initial page for goals and formatting with links for new lessons
revision.text:
= Goals =
Welcome to the second unit of the Elementary Spanish guide! Congratulations on your hard work so far.
In these lessons you will learn how to talk about jobs. Like the last unit "[[../Present_Family/|Family 1]]" the material in this unit will will be in the present tense so it will focus on talking about the job you have today or your conversation partner's job.
By the end you will be able to talk about basic kinds of jobs and working environments as well as share your opinions about them.
= Lessons =
Just like the last unit, all of these lessons focus on the same topic but each one is focused on the material you need to talk with different groups of people. You should start with the first lessons, "[[/Talking with each other/|1. Talking with each other]]", and then proceed to the rest as you have time. The language exchange events will only focus on these "Talking with each other" lessons so no need to worry if you do not have time for the other ones before the next meeting.
* '''[[/Talking with each other/|1. Talking with each other]]''' * '''[[/Talking with your children/|2. Talking with your children]]''' * '''[[/Talking with acquaintances/|3. Talking with acquaintances]]'''

revision.text:
==Key to Aves== *[[../Phoenicopteridae/|Phoenicopteridae]]: Large light pink to scarlet web-footed wading bird; Bill bent downward; Birds of brackish lakes. Flamingos. *[[#2|2]]: Feet lobed or unlobed; small to large birds of various colors.
==2== *[[#3|3]]: Legs are small; Feet covered with bare skin; Long wings, but short and stout humerus bones. *[[#4|4]]: Legs small to large; Feet covered with scales called scutes.
==3== <!-- Trochilidae (hummingbirds) Apodidae (swifts) Hemiprocnidae (treeswifts) --> *[[../Trochilidae/|Trochilidae]]: Beak long and thin; Wings flap very rapidly, allowing it to hover; Generally feed on nectar. Hummingbirds. *[[#5|5]]: Beak short; Does not generally flap wings very rapidly; Usually insectivorous.
==4== *[[#6|6]]: Nocturnal and carnivorous, feeding mostly on insects and small rodents; generally fly almost silently; Feathers have few radiates and longer pennulum; Large, tubular shaped eyes unable to move; Ear placement asymmetrical. Owls. *[[#7|7]]: Nocturnal or diurnal with various feeding habits; Generally make noise during flight; Small, round eyes.
==5== *[[../Apodidae/|Apodidae]]: Not able to perch; Tail not deeply forked; Crest not present on head. Swifts. *[[../Hemiprocnidae/|Hemiprocnidae]]: Able to perch; Tail deeply forked; Crest present on head. Treeswifts.
==6== *[[../Strigidae/|Strigidae]]: Inner toe shorter than third toe, which has a smooth edge; Circular facial disk; Four notches present in sternum which is not fused to the furcula. True owls. *[[../Tytonidae/|Tytonidae]]: Inner toe is the same size as other toes and has a pectinate claw; Heart-shaped facial disk; Two notches present in sternum which is fused to the furcula. Barn owls.
==7== *[[#8|8]]: Strong, curved bill; Two clawed toes face forward and two clawed toes face backward; Generally vividly multi-colored and eat seeds, nuts, fruit, buds, or other plant material. *[[#9|9]]: Various bill shapes, but generally not strongly curved downward; Various dactyly, but generally not two claws forward and two backward.
==8== incomplete
*Cacatuoidea (cockatoos), 21 species *Psittacoidea (true parrots), 330 species *Strigopoidea (New Zealand parrots), 9 species (excluding Kakapo- flightless)
==9== *[[#10|10]]: Sharply hooked beak with a cere on the proximodorsal surface; Strong legs with talons, including an opposable hind claw; Generally carnivorous and relatively long-lived. Raptors *[[#11|11]]: Beaks of various sizes, but generally don't have a cere (few exceptions including turkeys, skuas, and curassows).
==10== incomplete
*Accipitridae (eagles, hawks, old world vultures) *Pandion haliaetus (Osprey), 1 species *Falconidae (Falcons & caracaras), ~60 species *Sagittariius serpentarius (Secretarybird), 1 species *Cathartidae (New World vulture), 7 species
==11== *[[#12|12]]: Tubular nasal passage present, capable of smelling; Majority of food comes from the open ocean; Bill made up of seven to nine horny plates. Tubenoses. *[[#13|13]]: Tubular nasal passage absent; Majority of food terrestrial or of smaller bodies of water; Bill not made up of horny plates.
==12== incomplete
*Diomedeidae (albatrosses), 21 species (debated) *Hydrobatidae (storm petrels), 7 species *Pelecanoididae (diving petrels), 4 species *Procellariidae, ~70 species
==13== *[[w:en:Opisthocomus hoazin|Opisthocomus hoazin]]: spiky reddish-brown crest present on head; Unfeathered blue face and red eyes; Manure-like odor. *[[#14|14]]: Crest absent or if present, not spiky and reddish-brown.
==14== *[[../Podicipedidae/|Podicipedidae]]: Plumage is dense and waterproof; the underside the feathers are at right-angles to the skin, sticking straight out to begin with and curling at the tip. Grebes. *[[#15|15]]: Plumage may or may not be waterproof, but if it is, feathers not at right angles to skin.
==15== incomplete <!--Caprimulgiformes, Charadriformes, Ciconiiformes, Pelecaniformes, Gaviidae, Passeriformes, Coraciiformes, Piciformes, Bucerotiformes, Trogoniforems, Coliidae, Gruiformes, Leptosomatidae, Anseriformes, Galliformes, Rhynochetidae, Eurypygidae, Aegothelidae, Pteroclididae, Otididae, Phaethontidae, Columbidae, Cariamidae, Mesitornithidae, Cuculiformes-->

revision.comment: Alternative syntax to avoid the error
revision.text:
Exercise "Select the name and price of all products with a price larger than or equal to $180, and sort first by price (in descending order), and then by name (in ascending order)."
shows an error saying that I can't sort by name. Probably needs different data type
Alternative Syntax that can be used to avoid the error :
ORDER BY Product.Price DESC, CAST(Product.Name AS nvarchar(50))

page.title: Elementary Spanish/Future Weekend Plans/Talking with each other

revision.text:
== Goals ==
== Vocabulary == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Weekend_Beginner_Vocabulary Word match activity]
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Want | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Querer
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Doing | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Haciendo
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Going | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Ir
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Weekend | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Fin de semana
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Que
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Donde
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Cooking | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Cocinando
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Or | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| O
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Eating out | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Comer en la calle / comer fuera
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Will | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Vamos a
|} Querer
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| YO | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Quiero ______
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Tu | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Quieres ____
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| El/ella | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Quiere ____
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Ellos | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Quieren ____
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Nosotros | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Queremos ____
|}
For example: I want to go to the store. Yo quiero ir a la tienda.
           He wants to see a movie. El quiere mirar una película.
For example: We will go to school tomorrow. Vamos a la escuela mañana.
==Possible questions for language exchange==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What are you doing _______? (this weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Qué vas hacer ______? (este fin de semana, mañana, etc.)
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where are you going ______? (This weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Dónde vas _____? (este fin de semana, mañana, etc.)
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Are you cooking or eating out? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Vas a cocinar o comer afuera?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How will you get there? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cómo vas a ir allí?
|} “Are you going____?” is translated to “¿Vas ____?”
VOY
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Yo | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| voy a
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Tu | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| vas a
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| El/Ella | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| va a
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Ellos | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| van a
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Nosotros | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| vamos a
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlans-Part1 Question match practice]
== Dialogues == ''In the following dialogue, Pablo shares his weekend plans with Jorge.''
Jorge: ¿Qué vas a hacer este fin de semana?
Pablo: Quiero pasarla con mi familia.
Jorge: ¿Qué quieres hacer con tu familia?
Pablo: Quiero comer comida deliciosa con mi familia.
Jorge: ¿Vas a cocinar o comer en un restaurante?
Pablo: Yo voy al mercado de agricultores para comprar productos locales con mi familia entera.
Jorge: ¡Eso suena excelente!
Pablo: Tenemos conversaciones de las vitaminas en cada fruta y vegetal que compramos.
Jorge: Eso es muy impresionante. ¿Cómo llegan al mercado de agricultores?
Pablo: Normalmente, caminamos por en parque hacia Grand Army Plaza.
Jorge: Suenan como planes muy saludables para el fin de semana.
== Links and Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/Weekend_Beginner_Vocabulary Word match activity] * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlans-Part1 Question match practice]

== Possible questions to ask your child ==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What do you want to do ____? (this weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Qué quieres hacer ____? (este fin de semana, mañana)
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where do you want to go ____? (this weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Dónde quieres ir ____? (este fin de semana, mañana)
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What will we need to buy? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Qué vamos a necesitar comprar?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Would you like to have a playdate ____? (this weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Quieres tener una cita de jugar _____? (este fin de semana, mañana)
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Who would you like to see ____? (this weekend, tomorrow, etc.) | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Quién quieres mirar ______? (este fin de semana, mañana)
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlanning-Part2 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == ''In the following dialogue, Isaiah plans the day with his son, Javier. ''
Isaiah: Hola, corazón. ¿Qué quieres hacer este fin de semana?
Javier: ¡Quiero tener una cita de juegos con Carla!
Isaiah: Perdon, corazón. No podemos tener una cita de juegos con Carla. La familia de Carla acamparan este fin de semana.
Javier: O. Entonces quiero ir a la playa.
Isaiah: ¿Quieres ir al mercado de agricultores en la mañana y luego tener un picnic en la playa en la tarde?
Javier: Eso suena divertido. ¿También podemos llevar cosas para dibujar? Quiero dibujar cosas en la playa.
Isaiah: Si, corazón. ¿Qué quieres hacer para anochecer?
Javier: ¿Podemos ir al cine?
Isaiah: Vamos a mirar que cansado estas después de la playa. Podemos mirar una película en la casa si estas muy cansado.
Javier: ¡Esta bien!
== Links and Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlanning-Part2 Question practice activity]

== Goals ==
== Vocabulary ==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Bar | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| bar
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Drinking | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Voy a beber
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Dancing | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Voy a bailar
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Karaoke | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Voy a cantar karaoke
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Trivia | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Trivialidades
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Bike riding | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| andar en bicicleta
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Running | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Voy a correr
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Friends | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Amigos
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Girlfriend | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Novia
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Boyfriend | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Novio
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Co-workers | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Compañeros de trabajo
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Cost | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Costo
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Dollars | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Dólares
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Cents | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Centavos
|}
== Possible questions for a stranger ==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Who will you go with? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Quién va ir con nosotros?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Will there be room for one more? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Va ver campo para uno mas?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How long will it take? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cuánto tiempo va durar para llegar?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How much will it cost? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cuánto va a costar?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Will there be a cover? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Va ver un costo para la entrada?
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise:[http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlanning-Part3 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == ''In the following dialogue, three roommates make weekend plans to go dancing. Lucky for them, Julian’s girlfriend, a professional chef, will be in town for the weekend and able to cook for them. ''
Isabelle: ¡Hola compañeros de habitación! ¿Qué quieren hacer este fin de semana?
Julian: No se.
Margarita: ¡Yo quiero bailar!
Isabelle: Eso suena muy divertido. Yo no e bailado en mucho tiempo.
Julian: Mi novia viene de visita. También le gustaría bailar a ella.
Margarita: Que bueno. ¿Debemos cenar en un restaurante antes de bailar?
Isabelle: Yo prefiero ahorrar dinero y cocinar en el apartamento.
Julian: Mi novia es un chef profesional y le encantaría cocinar para nosotros.
Margarita: ¡Que fortuna para nosotros!
Isabelle: Margarita y yo compraremos las provisiones para la cena.
Julian: Apreciarla eso mucho.
Margarita: ¡Que bien!
== Links and Resources == * [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-WeekendPlanning-Part3 Question practice activity]

== Possible questions to ask a stranger ==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Why did you move to this area? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Por qué te moviste a esta área?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What motivated you to move here? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Qué te motivo mudarte aquí?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How long have you been in New York? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cuánto tiempo tienes en nueva york?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How old were you when you moved here? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cuántos año tenías cuando te mudaste a nueva york?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Are you visiting or living here? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Estas visitando o vives aquí?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Have you been to_____? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Has ido ha ______?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Who raised you? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Quién te crío?
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family2-Part1 Question practice activity]
== Dialogues == ''In the following dialogue, James and Janet talk about their school experience. They went to neighboring schools that were very different.''
James: ¡Tu fuiste a la escuela alrededor de la esquina de la mía!
Janet: ¿Yo? Yo nisabíaa que había una escuela cerca de mi.
James: Era una escuela pequeña y religiosa.
Janet: Mi escuela era enorme. ¿Cuántos estudiantes tenía tu escuela?
James: Mi escuela tenía una clase de kinder hasta el octavo grado. Habían como diez estudiantes por clase.Había menos de cien estudiantes en la escuela entera.
Janet: Wow. Eso si es pequeño. Nosotros teníamos más de mil estudiantes. ¿Te gusto?
James: ¡Me encantaba!
Janet: ¿Eras un buen estudiante?
James: Aprendí y escuchaba a la maestra.
Janet: ¿Jugaste deportes?
James: Yo participe en cada deporte que podía. Yo estaba en baloncesto, béisbol; yo corrí y también ayude con el equipo de voleibol de las muchachas.
Janet: Wow. ¡Tu estabas en todo!
James: Era una escuela bien pequeña.
* [http://wikiotics.org/es/Past_Education_Beginner_Dialogue Audio lesson activity]

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Christmas | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Navidad

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Hanukkah | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Hanukkah
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Winter Solstice | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Solsticio de Invierno

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Day of the Dead | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Día de los Muertos
|}
== Possible questions for language exchange ==
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| What will you be celebrating? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Qué vas a celebrar?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How will you be celebrating? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cómo vas a celebrar?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Who will you be celebrating with? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Con quien vas a celebrar? ¿Quién va celebrar con tigo?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where will you go? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Dónde vas a ir?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How will you get there? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cómo vas a viajar allí?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| How long will you be there? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Cuánto tiempo vas estar allí?
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-HolidayPlans-Part1 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Future_Holidays_Podcast_Beginner Audio lesson activity]
Tanicia: ¡Feliz días de fiestas!
Lucrecia: ¡Feliz fiestas para ti y tu familia.
Tanicia: ¿Qué vas a celebrar esta época de fiestas?
Lucrecia: Este año vamos a visitar mi familia en Minnesota. Eso indica que vamos a celebrar solamente Navidad este año.
Tanicia: ¿Cómo celebras Navidad con tu familia?
Lucrecia: Mi mama, mis hijos y yo asemos tamales en la cocina juntos.
Tanicia: Mm, que rico. ¿Me guardas unos?
Lucrecia: Por supuesto. ¿Qué vas a celebrar este época de fiestas?
Tanicia: Vamos a celebrar Kwanza este año.
Lucrecia: ¿Vas a un lugar?
Tanicia: Vamos a la casa de unos amigos que viven cercas. Vamos a cocinar juntos y pasar tiempo juntos.
Lucrecia: Vamos a tener un gran tiempo este época de fiestas.

== Possible questions for your child ==

|}
===“Would like” conjugations===

Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-HolidayPlans-Part2 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Future_Holidays_Intermediate Audio lesson activity]
James: ¿Cómo quieres decorar el apartamento este para las fiestas?
Melissa: Quiero ensatar palomitas juntas para decorar el árbol.
James: Eso suena divertido. ¿Quieres decorar las paredes también?
Melissa: No. Solamente quiero decorar el árbol.
James: ¿Quieres hacer adornos para el árbol?
Melissa: Si. Quiero hacerlos con papel de construcción.
James: ¿Qué quieres comer para las fiestas? ¿Debemos cocinar en casa o ir a la casa de abuela?
Melissa: Debemos ir a la casa de abuela y comer lo que ella quiera cocinar.
James: Tienes muy buenas ideas. Abuela cocina muy rico.

|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| House of worship | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Casa de Dios

|} ===Possible questions for a stranger===
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Did you celebrate that growing up? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Celebraste eso creciendo?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Do you celebrate that with family or the community? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Celebras eso con tu familia o con la comunidad?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Are there special foods? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Hay comidas especiales?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Do you wear anything special? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Usas ropa especial?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Do you celebrate ____ somewhere special? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Celebras ______ en un lugar especial?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Is that like _____? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Eso es como ____?
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-HolidayPlans-Part3 Question practice activity]
== Dialogue == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Future_holidays_Advanced Audio lesson activity]
Erica: Buenos días.
Alejandro: ¡Buenos días!
Erica: ¿Qué celebraste cuando estabas creciendo?
Alejandro: Celebrábamos día de los muertos.
Erica: Eso suena espantoso. ¿Es como Halloween?
Alejandro: No. Casi nada tienen similar. Es una manera de celebrar gente en nuestra familia que estabas vivos pero ahora están muertos. La muerte es parte de la vida.
Erica: ¿Usan ropa especial?
Alejandro: Una gente usa ropa tradicional de nuestros antepasados. Las mujeres usan vestidos muy lindos y anchos de muchos colores. La gente le gusta pintar su cara de calaveras.
Erica: Muy interesante.

== Goals ==
== Vocabulary ==

== Goals ==
== Vocabulary == [http://wikiotics.org/es/Extended_family Word match activity]
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Grandma | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| abuelita
abuelo
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Grandpa | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Abuela
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Step-sister | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Hermanastra
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Step-brother | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Hermanastro
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Aunt | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Tía
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Uncle | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Tío
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Nephew | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Sobrino
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Niece | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Sobrina
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Cousin | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Primo /prima
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Godmother | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Madrina
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Godfather | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| padrino
|}
=== Possible questions to ask your child ===
{| style="border-spacing:0;" | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where was ___ born? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Dónde nació____?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Where did ____ grow up? | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ¿Dónde se crío ______?
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ____ was born in _____. | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ____ nació en _____.
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| I was born in ________. | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Yo nací en _______.
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| I grew up _________. | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| Yo me críe en _______.
|- | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| _______ grew up __________. | style="border:0.05pt solid #000000;padding:0.0799in;"| ____ de crío en ______.
|}
Practice with these terms in this interactive exercise: [http://wikiotics.org/es/ElementarySpanish-Family2-Part2 Question practice activity]
If you child is ready, I encourage them to interview a Spanish speaking relative or Spanish speaking family friend!
== Dialogue == ''In the following dialogue, Tanicia tells her mom, Lucrecia all she learned in school that day.''
Tanicia: ¡Hola mami!
Lucrecia: Hola, cariño. ¿Cómo estuvo tu día hoy?
Tanicia: Bien.
Lucrecia: ¿Qué aprendiste hoy?
Tanicia: Nada.
Lucrecia: ¿Nada? Vamos a mirar en tu cuaderno.
Tanicia: Esta bien.
Lucrecia: Noto que aprendiste sumar dos números en matemática hoy.
Tanicia: Si.
Lucrecia: ¿Cómo sumas dos números? ¿Me pueden mostrar?
Tanicia: Si. Tengo dos dedos y tengo tres dedos y luego los pongo juntos. Ahora tengo cinco dedos.
Lucrecia: Hiciste un trabajo excelente sumando usando tus dedos. ¿Qué aprendiste de mapas hoy?
Tanicia: Aprendí cómo dibujar una brújula estrella.
Lucrecia: ¿Me puedes enseñar como dibujar una brújula estrella?
Tanicia: necesito un lápiz y papel.
Lucrecia: Lo que tu necesites, cariño.
[http://wikiotics.org/es/Past_Family_Intermediate_Dialogue Audio lesson activity]
